chapter.title: Getting Started Guide for Creating a Struts Application
chapter.para: We are going to show you how to create a simple Struts application using the JBoss Developer Studio. The completed application will ask a user to enter a name and click a button. The resulting new page will display the familiar message, "Hello <name>!"

This document will show you how to create such an application from the beginning, along the way demonstrating some of the powerful features of JBoss Developer Studio. You will design the application, generate stub code for the application, fill in the stub coding, compile the application, and run the application all from inside JBoss Developer Studio.

We assume that you have already launched Eclipse with JBoss Developer Studio installed and also that the Web Development perspective is the current perspective. (If not, make it active by selecting Window > Open Perspective > Other > Web Development from the menu bar.)

section.title: Starting Up
section.para: We are first going to create a new project for the application.

listitem.para: Go to the menu bar and select File > New > Project....
Select JBoss Tools Web > Struts > Struts Project in the New Project dialog box
Click Next
Enter "StrutsHello" as the project name
Leave everything else as is, and click Next
Click Next again
Make sure that struts-bean.tld, struts-html.tld, and struts-logic.tld are checked in the list of included tag libraries and then click Finish

section.para: A "StrutsHello" node should appear in the upper-left Package Explorer view.

listitem.para: Click the plus sign next to StrutsHello to reveal the child nodes
Click the plus sign next to WebContent under StrutsHello
Click the plus sign next to WEB-INF under WebContent
Then, double-click on the struts-config.xml node to display a diagram of the Struts application configuration file in the editing area

section.para: At this point, its empty except for the background grid lines.

section.title: Creating the Application Components
section.para: Now, we will design the application by creating the individual components as placeholders first. (We dont have to complete all of the details inside the components until afterwards.)

section.title: Creating JSP Page Placeholders
section.para: Next, let's create and place two JSP pages. We will not write any code for the files, but only create them as placeholders so that we can create links to them in the diagram. We will write the code a little bit later.

section.title: Creating the Page Placeholders

listitem.para: Bring the Web Projects view to the front of the Package Explorer view by selecting the Web Projects tab next to that tab.
Right-click the StrutsHello > WEB-ROOT (WebContent) folder in the Web Projects view and select New > Folder...
Enter pages for a folder name and click Finish
We will keep our presentation files in this folder
Right-click the pages folder and select New > Fila > JSP...
For Name type in inputname (the JSP extension will be automatically added to the file), for Template select StrutsForm and then click on the Finish button
Right-click the pages folder again and select New > File > JSP...
For Name type in greeting, for Template leave as Blank, and then click on the Finish button

section.para: Just leave these files as is for now.

section.title: Placing the Page Placeholders
section.para: Lets now place the two pages just created on the diagram.

listitem.para: Click on the struts-config.xml tab in the Editing area to bring the diagram to the front
Click on the inputname.jsp page in the Web Projects view, drag it onto the diagram, and drop it

itemizedlist.listitem: Click on the greeting.jsp page in the Web Projects view, drag it onto the diagram, and drop it to the right of the /pages/inputname.jsp icon with some extra space

section.para: You should now have two JSP pages in the diagram.

section.para: One last component that we need to create in the diagram is a global forward.

Select the Change...button for Path

section.title: Creating a Form Bean
section.para: One last thing that we need to do is to create a form bean.

listitem.para: Switch to the Tree viewer in the editor for the struts-config.xml file, by selecting the Tree tab at the bottom of the editor window
Right-click struts-config.xml > form-beans and select Create Form Bean
Enter GetNameForm in the name field and sample.GetNameForm for type
Click Finish
To save your changes to struts-config.xml, select File > Save from the menu bar

section.para: Note the disappearance of the asterisk next to the name, struts-config.xml.

section.title: Generating Stub Coding
section.para: We are done with designing the application through the diagram. Now we need to write code for the action component. We also need to write an action class for the /greeting mapping along with a FormBean. To aid in the coding phase, JBoss Developer Studio can generate Java class stubs for all of the components shown in the diagram.

listitem.para: Switch back to the diagram, by selecting the Diagram tab at the bottom of the editor window
Right-click a blank space in the diagram and select Generate Java Code
Leave everything as is in the dialog box and click Generate

section.para: You should see a screen that says:
Generated classes: 2
Actions: 1
Form beans: 1

listitem.para: Click Finish

section.para: The Java files will be generated in a JavaSource > sample folder that you can see in the Package Explorer view under the "StrutsHello" node. One Action stub and one FormBean stub will have been generated.

section.title: Compiling the Classes
section.para: Because this is the Eclipse environment, no explicit compilation step is required. By default, Eclipse compiles as you go.

section.title: Running the Application
section.para: Everything is now ready for running our application without having to leave JBoss Developer Studio by using the JBoss Application Server engine that comes with the JBoss Developer Studio. For controlling JBoss AS within JBoss Developer Studio, there is JBoss Server view.

listitem.para: Start up JBoss AS by clicking on the icon in JBoss Server view. (If JBoss AS is already running, stop it by clicking on the red icon and then start it again. Remember, the Struts run-time requires restarting the servlet engine when any changes have been made.)

After the messages in the Console tabbed view stop scrolling, JBoss AS is available. At this point, right-click on the getName global forward in the struts-config.xml diagram view and select Run on Server.

section.para: The browser should appear with the application started.
